Qizilbash

Unique replacement for the Lancer. Generates +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith, +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, and +2 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points every turn in enemy territory. Can always be purchased with [ICON_PEACE] Faith. Only the Persians may build it.

The Qizilbash is the Unique Persian replacement for the Lancer. Stronger than the Lancer, the Qizilbash also generates Faith, Gold and Golden Age Points for every turn they spend in enemy territory. This unit can also be purchased with Faith without needing a religious tenet. Maintaining a strong presence in enemy territory allows Persia to generate Faith for more Qizilbash, and trigger more Golden Ages to increase your army's power.

Qizilbash was originally a pejorative for the followers of the Safawiyyah Sufi order, who distinguished themselves by wearing bright crimson headwear. The name, which means red headed, became a mark of pride among the Qizilbash, who organized into a Shi'ite Islamic military society in the late 15th century. Though primarily of Turkman origin, the Qizilbash proved instrumental in the establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in Iran.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In a campaign to avenge the death of his father Haydar, Ismail I, led 7000 Qizilbash warriors to destroy the Aq Qoyunlu force of 30 000 in Azerbaijan, and establish the Safavid State. By 1510, eleven years later, Ismail brought all of Iran under his control, the first ethnically Iranian monarch to unify Iran in over 850 years. Though they had made him a powerful king, Ismail feared the power and influence of the tribal qizilbash over the Iranian peoples. Ismail and his successors would spend the next 80 years diminishing the political power of the Qizilbash, replacing them with ghulam slave soldiers from the Caucasus. Nevertheless, the Qizilbash held an honoured position within the Safavid empire, both on the battlefield and in the Safavid court.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]
Mughal Fort

Unique replacement for the Castle. 10% of [ICON_FOOD] Food is converted into [ICON_CULTURE] Culture every turn and 1 [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Artist Point. Contains 1 slot for a Great Work of Art. Gains +3 [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism at Flight. Requires Walls in City.

The Qila is the unique Indian replacement for the Castle. In addition to the normal bonuses of the Castle, the Qila generates Food, and Culture. 10% of [ICON_FOOD] Food is converted into Culture every turn and 1 Great Artist Point. Contains 1 slot for a Great Work of Art. Additional Tourism when Flight is Researched.

The Mughals were an Islamic empire that invaded India in the 15th century, and ruled most of the sub-continent until the mid 19th. During their rule, they constructed elaborate forts across the countryside which served as administrative centers and living quarters for the occupiers. These forts were beautiful structures, fitting palaces for the rulers of a vast empire. Several--including the magnificent "Lahore Fort" and Red Fort of Agra--survive today and remain as some of the largest tourist attractions to India, monuments to the Mughals' power and style.
Ranch

A ranch is a type of farm primarily for the raising of grazing livestock such as cattle or sheep. Ranching is also a method used to raise less common livestock such as elk, American bison or even ostrich, emu, and alpacas.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Ranches generally consist of large areas, but may be of nearly any size. If the ranch includes arable or irrigated land, the ranch may also engage in a limited amount of farming, raising crops for feeding the animals, such as hay and feed grains. As settlers from the United States moved west, they brought cattle breeds developed on the east coast and in Europe along with them, and adapted their management to the drier lands of the west by borrowing key elements of the Spanish vaquero culture. Vast swathes of the American interior were converted to ranchland in a process of colonization which left an indelible mark on the American psyche. Legends of the frontier, the Old West, Cowboys and Indians still permeate American culture, informing their sense of independence, enterprising spirit and mastery over nature.

The Ranch is the American replacement for the Stable. In addition to the regular abilities of the Stable, the Ranch increases border growth, and gives [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture when borders grow. Only America may build it.

Unique American Stable replacement. +33% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production when building Mounted Units. Increases the Military Unit Supply Cap from Population in the City by 10%.[NEWLINE]+25% border growth rate in city. Whenever the city borders expand, gain 10 [ICON_FOOD] Food and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, scaling with Era.
Riad

A riad is a traditional Moroccan house with an interior garden or courtyard. The riads were inward focused, which allowed for family privacy and protection from the weather in Morocco. In the central garden of traditional riads there are often four orange or lemon trees and possibly a fountain. The walls of the riads are usually adorned with Arabic calligraphy with quotes from the Quran.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The style of these riads has changed over the years, but the basic form is still used in designs today. Recently there has been a surge in interest in this form of house after a new vogue of renovation in towns such as Marrakech and Essaouira where many of these often-crumbling buildings have been restored to their former glory. Many riads are now used as hotels or restaurants.

The Riad is the Moroccan unique replacement for the Garden. In addition to the bonuses of a normal Garden, the Riad grants culture in the city for every 5 citizens in the city, and Gold generation in the city is greatly increased during a Golden Age. Trade routes originating from the city generate additional [ICON_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Merchant Points.

Unique Moroccan replacement for the Garden. Trade routes originating in the city gain +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Merchant Points per turn. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+30% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great People generation in this City. [NEWLINE]+15% [ICON_GOLD] Gold in the city during a [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age
Diplomatic Reciprocity

After creating an [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Embassy[ENDCOLOR] its yields are permanently added to your Capital's revenue if target City-State [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]is an Ally[ENDCOLOR] or only half, if it [COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]is not[ENDCOLOR] one.
Sachem's Council

+1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture for every 5 [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens, +2 [ICON_DIPLOMAT] Great Diplomat Points, +2 [ICON_RES_PAPER] Paper +10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production of Diplomatic Units and 1 Civil Servant Specialist Slots.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]All Councils gain +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, and all Chanceries gain +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Global Happiness for every Defensive Pact or War.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Great Diplomats gain the [COLOR_GREEN]Diplomatic Reciprocity[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_FOOD] Food in City for every City-State Friend, and +2 [ICON_PEACE] Faith for every Ally.

Unique Iroquoian replacement for the Scrivener's Office. In addition to the normal bonuses provided by the Scrivener's Office, the Sachem's Council provides faster generation of Great Diplomat units. Great Diplomats also receive a unique promotion, providing Science, Culture and gold for every embassy founded. All Councils in your empire also gain +1 Culture, and all Chanceries gain +2 Gold. The Sachem's Council also provides Happiness for every Defensive Pact and Declared War involving the Iroquois.

According to oral tradition, the five tribes of the Iroquois devoted much energy toward fighting and killing each other until the 1500s. It was at this time that the five tribes united into a powerful confederation, forming an elaborate political system including a bicameral (two-house) legislature much like the modern U.S. Congress. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In accordance with their unwritten constitution, the confederacy was represented by 50 delegates, or Sachems – all men, each chosen by the clan mother. The 17 sachems from the Seneca and Mohawk tribes met in one house while the 19 Oneida and Cayuga met in the other. The 14 Onondaga sachems acted as tie-breakers and had the power to veto decisions made by the others. In addition to Sachem, who met on Onondaga land to cast their votes, there were advisory council members called Pine Trees. Pine Trees could be men or women appointed for their heroic feats and accomplishments. In 1715 the Tuscarora joined the league, and it was renamed the League of Six Nations. Benjamin Franklin’s dealings with the Iroquois led him to model the United States’ government after theirs. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] “The soil of the earth from one end of the land to the other is the property of the people who inhabit it. By birthright the Ongwehonweh (original beings) are the owners of the soil which they own and occupy and none other may hold it. The same law has been held from the oldest times. The Great Creator has made us of the one blood and of the same soil he made us and as only different tongues constitute different nations he established different hunting grounds and territories and made boundary lines between them...” [NEWLINE] -Excerpt from the Iroquois Constitution
Sambadrome

Sambadrome (Sambódromo in Portuguese language) is the name given to an exhibition place for the Samba schools parades during Carnaval in Brazil. A sambadrome generally consists of tiered spectator viewing areas surrounding a long alley for the schools to parade down. The parades attract many thousands of Brazilians and foreign tourists each year.

The Sambadrome is the unique Brazilian replacement for the Opera House. In addition to the bonuses of an Opera House, it provides more Culture than the Opera House, and it also provides Golden Age Points and Tourism. The Sambadrome comes with a Musician specialist slot.

Unique Brazilian replacement for the Opera House. +7% [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in the City. +33% [ICON_GREAT_MUSICIAN] Great Musician Rate in the City, and all Musicians' Guilds produce +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +2 [ICON_GOLDEN_AGE] Golden Age Points. +3 [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism at Radio.
Scythe
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]On Move[ENDCOLOR] unit inflicts flat damage [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]to all new adjacent Enemy Units[ENDCOLOR]. +1 Sight.
Carnyx
+10% [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Ranged Combat Strength vs [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Archer and Melee Units[ENDCOLOR].
Scythed Chariot

A dangerous unit on open terrain. Only the Celts may build it. This unit is stronger against Archer and Melee Units, has more vision and ignores enemy Zone of Control. After moving, all newly adjacent enemy units take 10 damage. Moving into rough terrain ends all movement.

The Scythed Chariot is a Celtic unique unit made for destroying enemy lines. Enemies take damage whenever the Scythed Chariot moves adjacent to them, making this unit deadly in open terrain. Make every move count to maximize damage, but be careful not to leave your Chariots exposed to enemies on their turn. A mounted unit, the Scythed Chariot is vulnerable to Spearmen.

Scythed chariots are modified war chariots with long blades extending from the wheel axels. Though often dismissed as fanciful storytelling, the use of these war machines has been confirmed in at least a few more credible sources. Scythed chariots featured prominently during the Greco-Persian War, though to little effect against Macedon's well-trained infantry. Use of scythed chariots has been ascribed to Pictish, Irish and Iceni armies, but the claims are often of dubious validity. The only report of a scythed chariot in Britain outside of Roman propaganda comes from the Irish Ulster Cycle, during the adventures of Chu Chulainn. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Although chariots had fallen out of use in continental Europe from the end of the 3rd century BC, Caesar found that they remained significant in British warfare. Caesar encountered both Celtic cavalry and chariots and described how these warriors would throw javelins from their vehicles before dismounting to fight on foot. Celtic soldiers could return to their chariots to quickly retreat or redeploy. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] “They make war not only on horseback but also from 2 horse chariots and cars armed in the Gallic fashion – they call them ‘Covinni’ - on which they use axles equipped with scythes.” [NEWLINE] - Pomponius Mela
Crouching Tiger Cannon
+25% [ICON_RANGE_STRENGTH] Ranged Combat Strength vs [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Naval Units[ENDCOLOR].

Seir Morb

Unique Industrial Era Unit. Only the Siamese may build it. More powerful than the Field Gun it replaces and has a bonus against naval units instead of a penalty, but does not have the [COLOR_RED]Bonus vs Cities[ENDCOLOR] promotion. Deals more damage in a turn the less the unit has moved and receives [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Cover I[ENDCOLOR] and [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Cover II[ENDCOLOR] promotions for free.

A powerful coastal defense cannon, the Seir Morb is more powerful than the Field Gun it replaces, especially against naval targets, but deals less damage to cities. The Seir Morb receives a combat boost for every remaining movement point when attacking, so pick a good spot and keep it steady. Location, Location, Location.

Despite Siam's remarkable diplomacy, they did at times come into conflict with the great imperial powers which threated to swallow them whole. When the French set their sights on Laos, the Siamese mistakenly believed the English would aid them in their plight, and prepared for war. The Seir Morb ("Crouching Tiger") were the most technologically advanced cannons in the Siamese arsenal at the time; coastal artillery which could destroy any French boats foolish enough to enter their harbours. No amount of raw power, however, can account for corruption and disorganization. The French managed to establish their beachheads, and the coastal artillery of Thailand remained unused. It turns out that the proper use of a cannon involves firing it.
Shophet
Unique replacement for the Great General. Disembarks onto water tiles as a Great Admiral. Causes friendly units beginning in the same or adjacent tile to ignore enemy Zone of Control for that turn.

The Shophet is the unique Great General replacement for Carthage, for Hannibal. This unit causes all friendly units beginning in the same or an adjacent tile to ignore an enemy's Zone of Control for that turn. In addition, whenever this unit embarks into a water tile, it becomes a Great Admiral. It returns to Great General status upon disembarking into a city. Use a Shophet to supplement your military strategies when waging war against other civilizations.

In the various independent city states constituting Phoenicia proper (coasts of present Lebanon and Syria) and its "Punic" Mediterranean colonies a shofet (in Punic, suffet or suffete) was a non-royal magistrate granted control over a city-state, sometimes functioning much in the same way as a Roman consul.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The term is mostly widely known from the suffetes of Carthage, a former Phoenician colony. Following the overthrow of its monarchy in the 5th century BC, Carthage was ruled by a number of aristocratic councils presided over by two suffetes, who served in similar capacity to Roman consuls.

Shotel Swordsman

Unique Medieval Era Unit. Only the Ethiopians may build it. Has bonus damage against Mounted Units, unlike the Longswordsman it replaces. Enemies attacked by this Unit have -1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement on their next turn.
Unique Ethiopian replacement for the Longswordsman. This unit specializes in combating Mounted opponents and hobbling retreating units.

Shotel are dramatically curved double-edged swords used exclusively by the ancient Ethiopian Empire. Almost semicircular, the shotel could be used to hook shields, or even reach around them to strike an opponent. The sword could also be used to hook and unhorse a mounted soldier, bringing them to the ground. Warriors armed with Shotel were called 'Shotelai'. Elite corps of these Shotelai were employed by the armies of Amda Seyon I, comprising an elite force within his host.
SPAD S.VII

Unique Modern Era Unit. Only the French may build it. This Unit is cheaper, and has a longer range than the Triplane it replaces. Receives the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Quick Study[ENDCOLOR] Promotion for free.[NEWLINE]Does not require Oil.

The SPAD S.VII is France's early air superiority fighter. With a longer range and a cheaper cost and no need for oil, these fighters will help create a strong French presence in the air. The SPAD S.VII's quick study ability ensures these fighters are the toughest aces in the sky.

World War I saw rapid technological and tactical changes in how wars were fought, not the least of which was the first use of aircraft for scouting, support, and bombing. These new machines opened an entirely new theatre of war, a new avenue to gain an advantage over the enemy. Despite their promise, the first aircraft were slow, clumsy, and unreliable thanks to their underpowered combustion engines. This all changed in 1915 when Marc Birgikt invented a new V8 engine boasting 150 horsepower and weighing only 330 pounds. The French high command saw this new motor’s obvious value as an aircraft engine and set about in commissioning a new fighter aircraft designed around this new powerhouse: The Societe Pour L'Aviation et ses Derives, or ‘SPAD’ S. VII. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] By late 1916 SPAD VIIs were beginning to see action, and saw wide adoption by allied pilots for the rest of the war. Though lacking in maneuverability compared to the older Nieuport fighters, the SPAD VII more than made up for this deficiency in sheer speed, travelling in excess of 205kmph, and capable of safe dives of more than 400kmph. Entirely new tactics had to be created by pilots to leverage this unmatched speed, which gave the SPAD the ability to safely avoid or escape pitched battles. The added stability in diving was especially appreciated over the old Nieuports, which had a bad habit of shedding their wings during maneuvers. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Air superiority became a constant arms race against newer and better German designs and engines. By the end of the war, the SPAD VII's single .303 Vickers machine gun was outmatched by German fighters, which carried at least two machine guns. The heavier and faster SPAD XIII replaced the SPAD VII by late 1917, and would carry France to the end of the War. Though at times unreliable and hard to maneuver, the SPAD series would go down in history as the fastest and most powerful of WWI fighters, and continued to be used by the French as a training plane until it was retired in 1928.
Schützenstand

The Schützenstand were originally rifle guilds and rifle companies that had been formed in the 15th and 16th centuries, and were involved time and again in military operations within the borders of the Austrian County of Tyrol. A Standschütze was a member of a Schützenstand ("shooting club"), into which he was enrolled, which automatically committed him to the voluntary, military protection of the state of Tyrol (and Vorarlberg). In effect they were a type of Tyrolean local militia or home guard.

The Schützenstand is an Austrian unique building, replacing the Arsenal. It is cheaper than the Arsenal and provides more defense. It allows for faster construction of land military units in the city. It also provides +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture per city-state ally.

+2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture per city-state ally. +20% production toward land military units.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Increases city Defense Strength by 25 and Hit Points by 200. Military Units supplied by this City's population increased by 10%.
Tersane

Unique Medieval Era Building. [NEWLINE]When a Sea Trade Route originating here and targeting another Civ is completed, receive a [ICON_TOURISM] Tourism boost with the civ based on your recent [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+50% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards Cargo Ships and +30% [ICON_PRODUCTION] towards Naval Melee Units. Naval Melee Units trained in this City receive the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Prize Ships[ENDCOLOR] Promotion.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Only Ottomans may build it.

Tersane is the unique Harbor replacement of the Ottomans. In addition to the bonuses of a Harbor, the Tersane increases the yields of work boats. The building also greatly improves production towards trade and military vessels, greatly improving the Ottoman's naval capabilities. All Melee Ships built in this city also receive the Prize Ships promotion, allowing them to capture defeated enemy units.

The Turkish word 'Tersane' is derived from the Venetian 'darsane', from which the English word 'arsenal' is also derived. Though never at the forefront of shipbuilding technology, the Ottomans enjoyed over a century of naval dominance in the Mediterranean following their conquest of Constantinople in 1453. The largest Tersane, constructed at the Golden Horn across from Constantinople, housed over 160 docks, drydocks, storehouses and supply depots, making it one of the largest centers of trade, commerce and industry in the Mediterranean. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Ottoman naval power was maintained through its tremendous shipbuilding capacity, as well as its allegiances to the Barbary corsairs of North Africa. This pre-eminence was finally ended at the battle of Lepanto, where a combined Spanish and Venetian armada delivered a crushing defeat to the Ottoman's, capturing or destroying more than two thirds of the Ottoman's navy. Their response was to build 250 new vessels within six months. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] "You come to see how we bear our misfortune. But I would have you know the difference between your loss and ours. In wresting Cyprus from you, we deprived you of an arm; in defeating our fleet, you have only shaved our beard. [NEWLINE] Grand Vizier Mehmed Sokullu, on the defeat at Lepanto, and the capture of Cyprus, which the Ottomans had taken earlier the same year
Tophet

Provides [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in the City. [NEWLINE]Receive 10 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture in the City whenever a Unit is purchased, scaling with era, and Units purchased in this city receive full XP from buildings.

The Tophet is the unique Shrine replacement for Carthage. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Shrine, the Tophet provides Culture whenever a unit is purchased in the City. Military Units purchased in a City with a Tophet are not affected by the normal half XP penalty for purchasing.

"Tophet" is a Hebrew term for a place of worship and human sacrifice to the Canaanite gods, and has become a colorful synonym for hell within Judeo-Christian theology. Usually located outside cities, Tophets were holy places where sacrifices to the gods could be presented to the heads of the Phoenician pantheon, Ba'al Hammon, the god of weather and vegetation, and his consort, Tanit.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Regular sacrifices were made to ensure the prosperity of Carthage. After the ceremony, ashes of the burnt offering were placed within a vessel and stones were placed on top of the funerary urns to seal them within the Tophet. Child sacrifice, once prevalent throughout the Near-East, was a persistent hallmark of Carthaginian religious life long after contemporary cultures had shunned the practice. Modern archaeological evidence suggests children were sacrificed in times of great stress such as wars, plagues, and natural disasters as an act of divine supplication.
Purchasing a unit has earned you {1_num} [ICON_CULTURE] Culture from your Tophet in {2_Str}.
University of Coimbra

Opened in 1290, the University of Coimbra is one of the oldest centers of higher learning in the world, and the oldest in Portugal. The university was founded by King Dinis as the Lisbon Estudo Geral, originally with faculties of Arts, Law, Canon Law and Medicine. As the only university in Portugal for 350 years, the University of Coimbra became a focus of educational, political, and social influence in Portugal.

The Universiy of Coimbra is the unique Portuguese replacement for the Oxford University. It does not require a University, and provides a free University in the city. In addition to the normal bonuses of the Oxford University, it gives all naval units the ability to gain science from exploration, and generates Gold and Production in the city for every Feitoria built in foreign lands.

Unique Portuguese replacement for the Oxford University. Gain a free University, and a Great Scientist appears near the City. +75 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture every time you research a Technology, scaling with Era. Contains 2 slots for Great Works of Writing. Reduces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Illiteracy. +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to Universities. All naval units gain the Age of Discovery promotion. Whenever a Feitoria is built in city-state territory, permanently gain +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production Cost and [ICON_CITIZEN] Population Requirements increase based on the number of cities you own.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+3 [ICON_RESEARCH] Science if Themed.
Age of Discovery

Waag

Unique Dutch replacement for the Bank. Available earlier.[NEWLINE]When you spend [ICON_GOLD] Gold to purchase Units or invest in Buildings in this City, 15% of the cost is converted into [ICON_RESEARCH] Science. +3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to Caravansary and Customs House in this City, and +2 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to Market in this City.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2% [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Person Generation and +1 [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength in City for every Luxury Resource traded on Empire[NEWLINE]Reduces Poverty slightly.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_GOLD] Gold: +3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_SILVER] Silver: +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold, +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production, +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture.[NEWLINE]Nearby [ICON_RES_GEMS] Gems: +2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture, +1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold.

The Waag is the Netherlands' unique replacement for the Bank. In addition to the normal bonuses of a Bank, the Waag comes earlier than the Bank, and provides bonuses to Great Person Generation and defense for every luxury imported or exported in the Empire. Be sure to keep peaceful and lucrative relationships with your neighbors; a surprise war with a trading partner could suddenly weaken your city's defenses!

Waag ("weigh house") are the public buildings in which goods were weighed for market. Prior to international standards of weights and measures, the Waags performed an indispensable service in preventing the fraudulent sale of goods. As public control of the weight of goods was very important, Waags were run by local authorities who would also use them for the levying of taxes on goods transported through or sold within the city. This necessitated weigh houses be near a market square or town centre.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Of particular note is the Amsterdam Waag, built in the 15th-century on Nieuwmarkt square in Amsterdam. Originally, the building was one of the gates in the city wall along the moat formed by the current Singel canal. A number of guilds were housed on the top floors of the building: the blacksmiths' guild, the painter's guild, the masons' guild and the surgeons' guild, each with its own entrance gate. In 1632 Rembrandt van Rijn was commissioned to paint the surgeons at work, and the resulting The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp made his reputation. In 1691 a theatrum anatomicum was added, which became famous for admitting members of the public to witness human dissections.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]
White Tower

Unique replacement for the Hermitage. Only England may build it [NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture for every 4 [ICON_CITIZEN] Population in city. [NEWLINE]+2 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture for all Castles on Empire, and -25% Spy stealing rate on Empire [NEWLINE]+3 [ICON_GOLD] Gold to Constabulary and +3 [ICON_FOOD] Food to Arsenal in City. [NEWLINE]+1 [ICON_HAPPINESS] Happiness on Empire for every enemy spy killed on Empire. [NEWLINE]Contains 3 slots for Great Works of Art/Artifact, and comes with a free Great Work of Art. [NEWLINE]+5 [ICON_GOLD] Gold and +5 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture when themed. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Available earlier, requires Castle in City.

Unique English replacement for the Hermitage. This National Wonder produces +1 Culture for every 4 Citizens in the City, and 2 culture for every castle in the empire. The White Tower reduces the stealing rate of enemy spies on empire, and gives Happiness for every enemy spy killed. Your citizens will love you if you can keep a tight lid on English secrets, so station spies in your cities to take advantage of this wonder.

The White Tower is a central tower, the old keep, at the Tower of London. It was built by William the Conqueror during the early 1080s, and subsequently extended. The White Tower was the castle's strongest point militarily, and provided accommodation for the king and his representatives, as well as a chapel. The Tower of London covers an area of 18 acres and its magnificent architecture covers almost all the styles which have flourished in England. Throughout its long history, the Tower has been many things to England: A tyrant's castle, and treasury; a menagerie, and a mint; a palace, and a prison. Today, the Tower of London is a vast museum which boasts, among its many treasure, the Crown Jewels of England.
Treasury of {2_CivAdjective} Treasures

"On the contrary. Every Bison dollar will be worth five British pounds. For that is the exchange rate that the bank of England will implement after I kidnap their queen." [NEWLINE]-M. Bison
The Crown Jewels
Xiafan Guanjun
Sturdy Renaissance era ranged naval unit. Only China may build it.

The Xiafan Guanjun is a Chinese unique unit. It is much sturdier than the Frigate it replaces, is available earlier, and has the Supply promotion. When stationed in a city-state territory, gain 2 Influence with that city-state per turn.

The Xiafan Guanjun (lit. "The Foreign Expeditionary Armada") was the great treasure fleet of the Ming Dynasty. Seven voyages were made from 1405 to 1433 AD, all headed by the legendary admiral Zheng He at the behest of Yongle Emperor. The Treasure Fleet ranged as far as the Arabian Peninsula in their task of projecting Chinese influence across the South China Sea and beyond, bringing many smaller nations under the suzerainty of China.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]
The ships of the Xiafan Guanjun were some of the largest wooden ships ever constructed, some measuring an estimated 137 meters (416 feet). It would be another century before European ships could match the size and power of the Chinese, making China the undisputed naval superpower of the 15th century. Despite this raw power, the voyages were primarily concerned with diplomacy, bringing envoys and even kings before the emperor to present tribute and perform the 'kowtow', an act of reverence indicating their recognition and subservience to China.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]
"As an engine for carrying man and his commerce upon the high and stormy seas as well as on the vast inland waterways, it is doubtful if any class of vessel… is more suited or better adapted to its purpose than the Chinese or Indian junk, and it is certain that for flatness of sail and handiness, the Chinese rig is unsurpassed."[NEWLINE]-H. Warington Smyth
Kowtow
Can enter rival territory. +2 Influence per turn when stationed within a city-state's borders.
Yassa Court

Unique Classical Era Building which can be built in non-occupied cities. Eliminates [ICON_OCCUPIED] Extra Unhappiness from an Occupied City. +20% [ICON_PRODUCTION] Production towards Ranged, Siege, Mounted and Armor Military Units. Conquering enemy city starts 10-turn long [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] WLTKD. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Slightly reduces [ICON_HAPPINESS_3] Crime, Boredom, Illiteracy and Religious Tension. Building cost is slightly increased with number of Cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Only Mongols can build it.

Unique Mongolian replacement for the Courthouse. Can be built in non-occupied Cities. In addition elimination Unhappiness in Occupied Cities, this building reduces unhappiness from Crime, Illiteracy, Boredom and Religious Tensions, and increases production of all Land-based military units, except Unmounted Melee. Conquering Cities triggers a small WLTKD. It is also slightly cheaper than the Courthouse.

Yassa was a secret written code of law created by Genghis Khan. The word Yassa translates into "order" or "decree". It was the de facto law of the Mongol Empire even though the "law" was never actually made public. The Yassa seems to have originated from decrees issued in war time, and was later codified and expanded to include cultural and life-style conventions. By keeping the Yassa secret, the decrees could be modified and used selectively. It is believed that the Yassa was supervised by Genghis Khan himself with the help of the high judge of the Mongol Empire: His stepbrother, Shihihutag. Genghis Khan appointed his second son Chagatai (later Chagatai Khan) to oversee the execution of the laws.

Yellow Brow

Unique Renaissance Era Unit. Only the Shoshone may build it. This Unit is slightly stronger than the Tercio it replaces. Has the Anti-Cavalry promotion, fights at full strength when damaged, and has double the normal strength from fortifying.

The Yellow Brow is unmatched for its ability to hold ground. Never one to retreat, the Yellow brow fights at full strength regardless of health, and has double the normal bonus from fortifying. This unit is very effective against enemy cavalry

Yellow Brows (Ohamupe) were one of two military societies within the Shoshone, playing an integral role in hunting, scouting, and policing within their Shoshone bands. Yellow Brow braves would keep their heads shaved into a cockscomb 'mohawk', and paint their exposed heads yellow, hence their common English name. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The Yellow Brows were composed of only the bravest and most daring of the young men, tasked with keeping order on hunting expeditions, scouting, and soldiering. The Society was never more than a few hundred young men, and membership was through appointment by graduating members, who would elect their replacement. A young Yellow Brow was expected to act and speak in a contrarian way as a sign of membership. For instance, when asked if he would like to join the Yellow Brows, it was expected that the young man would say 'No' as a sign of willingness to join, or 'Yes' if he wished to decline. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] In battle, they were led by a warchief who carried a long cane tipped with a stone or metal dagger. The cane was used to grab and unhorse opponents, or as a No-Retreat signal. If the enemy was gaining the upper hand, the chief would drive his staff into the ground and the braves would defend him to the last. Yellow Brows were banned from leaving their chief's side until another member of the tribe came and pulled out the staff, releasing the braves from their charge. Fleeing battle after the staff had been planted resulted in dire consequences for any returning Yellow Brow. Such dishonorable conduct was met with abject mockery and banishment from the tribe.
